metadata.case_name: Automobile Transport (Rajasthan) Ltd. v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Appellants are Automobile Transport (Raj.) Ltd., Rajasthan Roadways Ltd., and Framji C. Framji and others, carrying on business of plying stage carriages.

First appellant had nine transport vehicles plying between Nasirabad and Deoli in Ajmer, and Ajmer to Kishangarh in Rajasthan; road from Nasirabad to Deoli mainly in Ajmer but passes through narrow strips of Rajasthan; Ajmer to Kishangarh partly in Ajmer (two-thirds) and partly in Rajasthan (one-third).
Second and third appellants had vehicles plying on Nasirabad-Deoli route or Kishangarh to Sarwar in Rajasthan.
Rajasthan Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1951 (Rajasthan Act XI of 1951) passed; rules promulgated thereunder.
Second respondent demanded tax from appellants for period April 1, 1951 to March 31, 1954: first appellant Rs. 22,260, second Rs. 6,540, third Rs. 10,260 under r. 23 of Rules.
Appellants failed to pay; second respondent issued certificates under s.13 of Act to third respondent for recovery as arrears of land revenue.
Second and third appellants filed appeals to Transport Commissioner under s.14; dismissed on October 21, 1953. First appellant did not appeal.
Appellants filed writ petitions Nos. 400 to 402 of 1954 in Rajasthan High Court contending Act violates Art.301.
Division Bench (Bapna and Bhandari JJ.) referred question on ss.4 and 11 infringing Art.301 to Full Bench.
Full Bench held restrictions reasonable under Art.19(1)(d),(g); from trade/commerce standpoint, tax indirect/sequential, not offending Art.301.
Division Bench dismissed writs on August 9, 1957; granted certificate under Art.132 on October 16, 1957.
Appeals heard by five-judge bench, referred to seven-judge bench on April 4, 1961 due to importance and Atiabari Tea Co.

Notices to Advocates-General; interveners: States of Andhra Pradesh, Assam, Bihar, Gujarat, Madras, Maharashtra, Orissa, Punjab, West Bengal; M.A. Tulloch & Co., Nazeeria Motor Service etc., Attorney-General.
In 1952-53, income from tax ~34 lakhs, road expenditure ~60 lakhs; 1954-55 estimated 35 lakhs income, 65 lakhs expenditure.

legal_issues.text: Whether ss.4 and 11 of Rajasthan Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1951 infringe freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse under Art.301, and not saved by Art.304(b).
Correct interpretation of Arts.301-304; whether majority view in Atiabari Tea Co. requires reconsideration; applicability to facts.

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of Act impose direct and immediate restriction on movement of trade/commerce, violate Art.301, not saved by Art.304(b) as no Presidential sanction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.301; Shah J.'s view in Atiabari Tea Co.

petitioner_arguments.text: Even on majority view in Atiabari, tax is direct restriction on movement.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. v. State of Assam

respondent_arguments.text: Tax is consolidated on vehicle (like property tax), not on carriage of goods; indirect effect only; differs from Atiabari.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.301 (taxation simpliciter not impediment); Chief Justice view in Atiabari

respondent_arguments.text: Tax compensatory for road maintenance; reasonable; facilitates trade.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects widest view (Shah J. in Atiabari): Art.301 not freedom from all burdens/regulations; regulatory measures/compensatory taxes not restrictions under Art.301.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Freedom under Art.301 in context of orderly society; compensatory taxes facilitate trade.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects narrow view: Taxation not outside Part XIII except Art.304(a); Art.301 applies to taxes that directly impede trade flow.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.245 subjects laws to Constitution including Part XIII.

court_reasoning.text: Accepts majority Atiabari view with clarification: Only direct/immediate restrictions on trade flow hit Art.301; regulatory/compensatory taxes excluded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Taxes for road use are compensatory if reasonable and linked to facilities provided.

court_reasoning.text: Act's tax is on vehicles using/kept for use on Rajasthan roads; rates based on type/capacity; payable annually; refund if unused 3 months; compensatory as revenue < road costs.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tax ~50% of road expenditure; e.g., Rs.10/day for 140 maunds goods = anna/maund.

holdings.text: Regulatory measures or compensatory taxes for trading facilities do not come within restrictions under Art.301; need not comply with Art.304(b) proviso.
Taxes under Rajasthan Act are compensatory for road use, do not violate Art.301.

precedents_cited.case_name: Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. v. State of Assam
precedents_cited.relevance: Majority view on direct restrictions on trade flow correct, with clarification on compensatory taxes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thakur Amar Singhji v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: History of Rajasthan constitution; competence of Rajpramukh upheld.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors
precedents_cited.relevance: States can impose non-discriminatory taxes on imported goods.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commonwealth of Australia v. Bank of New South Wales
precedents_cited.relevance: Regulation compatible with freedom; direct vs indirect restrictions.
Free does not mean extra legem.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hughes and Vale Pty. Ltd. v. State of New South Wales

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Freedom of trade/commerce; restrictions; saving clauses; interpreted to exclude compensatory taxes from Art.301 restrictions.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Imposition of tax on motor vehicles using roads; held compensatory.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Rajasthan High Court's dismissal of writ petitions; held tax under Rajasthan Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1951 compensatory for road use, not violating Art.301.

key_quotes.text: "Taxes may and do amount to restrictions but it is only such taxes as directly and immediately restrict trade that would fall within the purview of Art. 301."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Adopts and clarifies majority view from Atiabari.

key_quotes.text: "For the tax to become a prohibited tax it has to be a direct tax the effect of which is to hinder the movement part of trade. So long as a tax remains compensatory or regulatory it cannot operate as a hindrance."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The taxes imposed are really taxes on motor vehicles which use the roads in Rajasthan or are kept for use therein... compensatory taxes which instead of hindering trade, commerce and intercourse facilitate them by providing roads."
key_quotes.speaker: court
